title: As a Bake Off semi-finalist you know when it’s your turn to leave the tent
text:
I was once even recognised in Peru whilst trekking in the middle of nowhere (Picture: Tom Graham/ BBC)

It’s the semi-finals and the remaining bakers are wearing ties in a beautiful, unspoken tribute to Henry.

The judges definitely took things up a level this week and the final suddenly felt right around the corner. As I found out during my time in the tent, semi-finals are a funny thing; it’s an achievement in itself to get there yet leaving in a semi-final is also bittersweet. Emotions are everywhere and we question what you could’ve done better to stay.

It’s like going to Disneyland, having the time of your life looking forward to the final and best ride when suddenly there’s a power outage resulting in the park being evacuated and closed for the day – just picture that!

It was disappointing not to reach the final stage, but I was also grateful I’d come so far. It’s difficult to let the tent go after nine intense weeks; for it to suddenly stop is bizarre.

But it’s almost like you know when it’s your time to leave the tent – in my case I kind of knew and felt it. I was the weakest link and made far too many mistakes.

I recall the morning of the semis fondly, thinking this was it, so close yet so far. I woke up at 6:30 and listened to The Life of Pablo album, track two – Father Stretch My Hands Pt.1 – by Kanye West. It became a morning ritual to listen to that album, starting with that track in particular, during the entire series.

Every morning in my hotel room before we all met for breakfast, I’d put on my noise cancelling headphones, gather my thoughts and plan the day and how to tackle each challenge.

There was something spiritual/religious about that song. Unfortunately, the miracle ended for me that week but I always look on the bright side. I took from the show lessons and great experiences from the auditions all the way up to my elimination.

For me it was not goodbye because I knew I’d be back for the epic garden party and to see all the bakers again and meet their families. And I knew there would also be food and drinks – HALLELUJAH!!!

It’s almost like you know when it’s your time to leave the tent (Picture: Channel 4)

Bake Off is filmed over the summer but doesn’t air until the autumn, which makes it tricky to keep such big news quiet! Close friends and family knew I was taking part and swore under secrecy not to tell anyone, but I couldn’t share major details with them.

It’s quite funny watching your summer on Bake Off play out over several weeks on national television. Online comments and opinions (the irony of this column isn’t lost on me…) formed a slightly odd narration and at the time I remember thinking that it felt like my summer had almost happened to someone else.

While I was filming the show I was still in my day job and this didn’t change after it aired. What did change was the social media intensity and following that grew pretty rapidly after the first few episodes.

I was once even recognised in Peru whilst trekking in the middle of nowhere, and more recently in the middle of a lake in Switzerland by one other mad swimmer who had ventured out into the cold water! Fortunately for my colleagues I’m still just Selasi who bakes cakes and that’s really helped keep a sense of normalcy about the whole situation.

Having said that, I’m extremely fortunate that Bake Off also opened up a lot of opportunities I wouldn’t have been able to experience otherwise. I took a sabbatical and went to study at Culinary Arts Academy in Switzerland, an opportunity that came about as a direct result of Bake Off.

It meant I could study under professional chefs, spent an amazing week in Paris with Ritz Escoffier and gained a greater understanding of baking at a professional level for future ventures.

I’ve been able to host several pop-ups across London (my next one is being held at SMEG’s HQ on the night of the lights switch-on in Regent’s Street on 14th November) and most recently I’ve spent two weeks serving afternoon tea at Duke’s London, Mayfair alongside their amazing 3AA Rosette starred chef Nigel Mendham.

Advertisement

I’ve got lots more projects in the pipeline that I can’t talk about at the minute, but all that is to say that Bake Off changed my life in more ways than I could imagine.

I was also extremely lucky that the people I shared the tent with were a lovely bunch and we would organise viewing parties as each week unfolded. To this day we’re still in regular contact and see each other at various events.

It definitely made the overall experience much more enjoyable. I love them all and would not change the experience for anything. It was perfect.

This week was challenging and I’m sure the bakers felt the pressure, but you know what, they pulled through and they all delivered. I hope that Rosie can take away as much enjoyment from her time in the tent as I did.

The judges are certainly ready for the final and I hope the bakers are too! While they’re sat at home already knowing their fate, we’ll have to wait one more week to find out.

Either way, I hope they’re all celebrating their success so far and the adventure that’s just beginning for them.
